fact_check_explanation_title: Pouring diluted cordial onto a Covid-19 test won’t give an accurate result
fact_check_explanation_summary: A post on Facebook claims the tests are a ‘big farce’ because cordial appears to test positive.

fact_check_explanation_title: Was Michael Gove right about court ruling over bias in contracts?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The Cabinet Minister claimed on Sky News that there was no actual bias and no breach of the ministerial code in the decision to award a contract to Public First.

fact_check_explanation_title: Vaccinated people sometimes die of Covid-19—but very rarely
fact_check_explanation_summary: Many of the most at-risk people have been vaccinated, which is why figures from Public Health England show that some have still died.

fact_check_explanation_title: Only a third of people first heard of the term ‘cancel culture’ in the past year
fact_check_explanation_summary: An article in The Sun far overstates the number of people who have heard of cancel culture.

fact_check_explanation_title: What we know about Matt Hancock’s alleged use of private email
fact_check_explanation_summary: Downing Street initially denied accusations that Mr Hancock and Lord Bethell used private email addresses during the pandemic.

fact_check_explanation_title: World Economic Forum founder did not write book about ‘organised epidemics’
fact_check_explanation_summary: An essay passage that claims humanity will be wiped out by ‘organised epidemics‘ has been wrongly attributed to World Economic Forum founder Klaus Schwab

fact_check_explanation_title: How common is sexual abuse in schools?
fact_check_explanation_summary: An Ofsted survey did not show that 90% of girls experienced it, although it does appear to be a common problem, from other evidence.

fact_check_explanation_title: Ketchup, squash and fruit do not deliver positive Covid-19 results
fact_check_explanation_summary: Some foods can break a lateral flow test and cause a second line to appear. This rarely happens when the tests are used properly, on people.

fact_check_explanation_title: Critical report on BBC Newsround story is misleading
fact_check_explanation_summary: A report has criticised aspects of BBC childrens’ show Newsround’s coverage on Covid-19 vaccines but misleads in the process.
The Centre for Social Justice has described around 93,000 pupils as “severely absent” in the 2020 autumn term.

fact_check_explanation_title: Website makes false claims about vaccines and miscarriages
fact_check_explanation_summary: Daily Expose has claimed that the Covid-19 vaccine is to blame for dozens of miscarriages. There is no evidence for this.

fact_check_explanation_title: Telegraph suggests 9% of England dies each year
fact_check_explanation_summary: The article confuses an annual death rate with a monthly death rate.
